citation.article-title: Sarcobium lyticum gen. nov., sp. nov., an obligate intracellular bacterial parasite of small free-living amoebae.

p.s: Sarcobium (Sar. co’ bi. urn. Gr. n. sarcos, flesh; Gr. n. bios, life; M. L. neut. n. Sarcobium, that which lives in the sarcode or flesh [cytoplasm])
Motile by means of three to five polar flagella.
Cell division occurs by a transverse central pinching-off process.
The DNA base composition is 43 mol% guanine plus cytosine, as determined by the thermal denaturation method.
Chemotype A1A peptidoglycan with a free amino group on the glucosamine residues.
Obligate intracellular parasite of amoebae belonging to the Acanthamoeba-Naegleria group and related protozoa (e.g., Dictiostelium discoideum).
The bacterium is able to escape from parasitophorous vacuoles into the cytoplasm, where it proliferates.
